paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does the Earth-sized exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere, as inferred from JWST/MIRI thermal phase-curve spectroscopy and spectral structure near the 15 um CO2 band?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b JWST/MIRI phase-curve dataset
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One orbital phase curve with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Phase-resolved thermal spectra of TRAPPIST-1 b observed with JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy, capturing thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock (no-atmosphere) null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere-free interpretation assuming a bare rocky surface with minimal heat redistribution, used as the null model against which atmosphere-bearing retrievals are compared.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere-bearing retrievals with significant greenhouse gas absorption, motivated by spectral structure near 15 um and used to explore moderate-pressure CO2-rich solutions.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An alternative atmosphere-bearing retrieval family exploring oxidized (O2-rich) compositions, noted as not fully ruled out with current data and with weaker CO2 signature constraints.

major_limitations: Single-planet study; does not establish atmospheric prevalence across M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
